title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify that 4 units of Good F and 3 candy bars will maximize Courtney’s total benefit given her weekly income of $20 and/or does not explain that for the last unit of each good consumed the ratio of the marginal benefit to the price of Good F (5) is equal to the ratio of the marginal benefit to the price of candy bars (5), or

M B Good F Pric e Good F = M B Candy Bars Pric e Candy Bars MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6424@

$10 $2 = $20 $4 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@41C3@

5=5 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+=feaagCart1ev2aqatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLnhiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr4rNCHbGeaGqiFC0pg9uqGrpepeea0dXdHaVhbbe9u8qqaqFr0xc9pk0xj9qqaqFj0dh9qq=xfr=JarFfpeea0=as0=fs0di9uqFr0=vr0=vr0db8meaabaqaciGacaGaaeqabaWaaeaaeaaakeaaqaaaaaaaaaWdbiaaiwdacqGH9aqpcaaI1aaaaa@3BA0@

The response identifies that 4 units of Good F and 3 candy bars will maximize Courtney’s total benefit given her weekly income of $20 and explains that for the last unit of each good consumed the ratio of the marginal benefit to the price of Good F (5) is equal to the ratio of the marginal benefit to the price of candy bars (5), or

M B Good F Pric e Good F = M B Candy Bars Pric e Candy Bars MathType@MTEF@5@5@@6424@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate consumer surplus as $8 and/or does not show the work.

Consumer Surplus = Marginal Benefit−Price =   $12−$4 = $8 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@687C@

The response calculates consumer surplus as $8 and shows the work.

Consumer Surplus = Marginal Benefit−Price =   $12−$4 = $8 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@687C@

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that yes, Courtney would be able to buy 5 units of Good F and 2 candy bars and/or does not explain that her total expenditures would be $18 (=$2×5+$4×2) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44D0@ , which is equal to her weekly income of $18.

The response states that yes, Courtney would be able to buy 5 units of Good F and 2 candy bars and explains that her total expenditures would be $18 (=$2×5+$4×2) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@44D0@ , which is equal to her weekly income of $18.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the quantity of candy bars that will maximize Courtney’s total benefit will decrease and/or does not explain that an increase in the price of an input to the production of candy bars would decrease the supply of candy bars, which would increase the price of candy bars and decrease the marginal benefit per dollar spent for each additional unit consumed.

The response states that the quantity of candy bars that will maximize Courtney’s total benefit will decrease and explains that an increase in the price of an input to the production of candy bars would decrease the supply of candy bars, which would increase the price of candy bars and decrease the marginal benefit per dollar spent for each additional unit consumed.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify Good F and Good W as complements and/or does not explain that the cross-price elasticity of demand is negative because a 9% increase in the price of Good F led to a 3% decrease in the demand for Good W.

The response identifies Good F and Good W as complements and explains that the cross-price elasticity of demand is negative because a 9% increase in the price of Good F led to a 3% decrease in the demand for Good W.
